Los Tiempos de la Escucha es una exposic:
The Time(s) to Listen is an exhibition that invites us to connect with two textile collectives made up of women who have suffered the experiences of the war in Colombia, along with their feelings and testimonies regarding the question;
what shapes can reconciliation take?
Se trata de una oportunidad para descubr:
It is an opportunity to discover whispers , textures, colors and nuances that interweave textile and digital languages, to understand the ways in which the women imagine the paths and actions required to make peace possible in a country that is still at war. It is an invitation to prepare the body for listening, to measure the times that this demands and to reflect upon the power it has.

The Time(s) to Listen was brought to life by the union between a transdisciplinary research team from Bogotá and Medellín, and the women's collectives of Sonsón, Quibdó, Bojayá and Mampuján, who have for years embroidered, woven or sewn their memories about the damage caused by the armed conflict and imagined ways to mend life. The hand-crafted textiles and digital explorations came together to bring life to this exhibition, which in turn seeks to amplify the women’s stories and thereby invite us to be touched by what they share and teach.
Este Telón de la Reconciliación es una p: This Reconciliation Hand-embroidered cloth is a piece made by the women of the Artesanías Guayacán collective in May 2019. It is a fabric with yellow background that contains depictions of scenes and images of the daily life along the Atrato river, which the women embroidered as a representation of the feelings they associate with the word reconciliation. The development consisted, first, in a collective composition in which each member of the group contributed their idea so that Daisy Chana Picama, one of the indigenous members and the youngest of the group, could draw it. Using songs and verses, memories of the river and of chirimías (traditional songs), images of plantain trees, rice and elderberry crops, the women created an Atrato-like landscape, which had passed through everyone’s hands in order to, stitch by stitch, bring life to the shapes of reconciliation that sustains and strengthens them.

Mujeres tejiendo sueños y saberes de paz: Women Weaving Dreams and Flavours of Peace   |   Mampuján, María la Baja, Bolívar
Cerca de 20 integrantes del grupo de Tej: About 20 members of the group Tejedoras de Sueños y Sabores de Paz, inhabitants of the municipality of María Baja, meet one afternoon in May 2019 at the evangelical church in the neighborhood of el Recreo to collectively answer: What shape does reconciliation have? A conversation arises between them about the flavours, smells, sounds and textures that this word could hold. There’s laughter and anecdotes, recipes for turrón (nougat), coffee and mondongo (tripe soup), sweet, bitter and salty flavours that evoke the idea of foods favored in the region. The longing for music and dance becomes present, as well as the sounds that bring news and become omens. The ideas and drawings that are shared inspire the creation of the patchwork. Little by little, the shapes of a pot and the fire that represents the slow process of cooking arise. What flavours and dreams of reconciliation could the women be preparing?

→ Si tienes un tambor éste te ayudará a: → If you have an embroidery hoop it can help to stretch the fabric, which makes the task of embroidering easier and it ensures a more homogeneous end result, but using it is not necessary ;).
→ Corta un trozo de hilo, enhébralo en l: → Cut a piece of thread, pass it through the needle and tie a knot at one end. This will ensure that when you make the first stitch, the thread won’t pass straight through the fabric, it will remain attached to the fabric on one end.
→ We will start with the square in the middle. At one of the square’s corners, pass the needle through the back side of the fabric, and then take it to the opposite corner.

*Don’t worry about the neatness, enjoy the process, think about the messages that you listened to while you embroider.
